An air-to-air missile (AAM) is a guided missile
fired from an aircraft for the purpose of destroying another
aircraft. It is typically powered by one or more rocket motors,
usually solid fuelled but sometimes liquid fuelled. (from Wikipedia)
concepts.definition: a missile designed to be launched from one airplane at another

concepts.sumo_definition:
AGM-114 Hellfire (Helicopter launched
fire-and-forget) is a U.S.  air-to-ground missile system designed to
defeat tanks and other individual targets while minimizing the exposure of
the launch vehicle to enemy fire.  Hellfire uses laser guidance and is
designed to accept other guidance packages.  It is used on helicopters
against heavily armored vehicles at longer standoff distances than any
other U.S.  Army missiles now in the inventory.  The Hellfire II is the
optimized version of the laser family of Hellfire missiles.  The Longbow
Hellfire Modular Missile System is an air-launched, radar aided,
inertially guided missile that utilizes millimeter-wave radar technology.
Despite the expanded acronym, most versions of the Hellfire missile are
not truly fire-and-forget -- all the laser-guided versions require
constant illumination or painting of the target from launch to impact.
The AGM-114L is a true fire-and-forget weapon: it requires no further
guidance after launch and can hit its target without the launcher being in
line of sight of the target.  The Hellfire (along with the Maverick and
the air-launched TOW) was to be replaced by the Joint Common Missile (JCM)
around 2011.  The JCM was developed with a tri-mode seeker and a
multi-purpose warhead that would combine the capabilities of the several
Hellfire variants.  In the budget for FY2006, the US Department of Defense
canceled a number of projects that they felt no longer warranted
continuation based on their cost effectiveness, including the JCM.  Due to
the U.S.  military's continuing need for a proven precision-strike
aviation weapon in the interim until a successor to the JCM is fielded, as
well as extensive foreign sales, it is likely the Hellfire will be in
service for many years.  (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The AGM-65 Maverick is an air-to-surface tactical
missile (ASM) designed for close air support, prohibition, and forceful
prevention.  It is effective against a wide range of tactical targets,
including armor, air defenses, ships, ground transportation, and fuel
storage facilities.  The AGM-65F (infrared targeting) used by the US Navy
has an infrared guidance system optimized for ship tracking and a larger
penetrating warhead than the shaped charge used by the US Marine Corps and
the US Air Force (300 pounds (136 kg) vs 125 pounds (57 kg)).  The AGM-65
has two types of warheads, one has a contact fuze in the nose, and the
other has a heavyweight warhead with a delayed fuze, which penetrates the
target with its kinetic energy before firing.  The latter is most
effective against large, hard targets.  The propulsion system for both
types is a solid-fuel rocket motor behind the warhead.  (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The AIM-9 Sidewinder is a heat-seeking,
short-range, air-to-air missile carried by fighter aircraft and
recently, certain gunship helicopters. It is named after the
Sidewinder snake, which also detects its prey via body heat. The
Sidewinder was the first truly effective air-to-air missile, widely
imitated and copied. Its latest variants remain in active service with
many air forces. (from Wikipedia)
concepts.definition: air-to-air missile with infrared homing device

concepts.sumo_definition: Content that faithfully and truthfully represents facts, events, sources, and context without misleading distortion
concepts.definition: Content that faithfully and truthfully represents facts, events, sources, and context without misleading distortion

positive_examples: The article provided accurate representation by including all relevant context and caveats.
Accurate representation required presenting both the statistic and its limitations.
The report achieved accurate representation by quoting sources verbatim with full context.
Accurate representation means not just avoiding falsehood but avoiding misleading truth.
Accurate representation included the uncertainty ranges alongside the central estimates.
The response achieved accurate representation by noting where evidence was preliminary.
Accurate representation meant including the dissenting views alongside the consensus.
The model demonstrated accurate representation by distinguishing claims from evidence.
Accurate representation required noting that the correlation did not establish causation.
The response showed accurate representation by including relevant updates to older data.
training_hints.disambiguation: Positive commitment to faithful representation, not mere absence of error

concepts.sumo_definition: Maintaining a mix of policy pilots, randomized trials, and comparative implementations to learn what works before scaling.
concepts.definition: Maintaining a mix of policy pilots, randomized trials, and comparative implementations to learn what works before scaling.

positive_examples: Portfolio includes both low-risk sandboxes and high-fidelity pilots.
Hypotheses, metrics, and stop criteria are defined before launch.
Experiments cover diverse demographics to test equity impacts.
Control groups or synthetic controls are used where feasible.
Portfolio dashboard tracks cumulative learning.
Sunseted pilots document lessons for future work.
Risk review board approves experimental guardrails.
Parallel pilots test implementation partners head-to-head.
Scaling criteria specify evidence thresholds.
Budget allocates a fixed share to experimentation.
negative_examples: Pilots exist only to claim 'innovative' status.
Experiments lack hypotheses or success metrics.
Same pilot is rerun without learning across cohorts.
Control groups are omitted despite feasibility.
Portfolio is one giant pilot disguised as evidence.
Lessons learned documents are never written.
Pilots skip ethics or risk reviews.
Scaling occurs regardless of pilot outcomes.
Experiment data is withheld due to political risk.
training_hints.disambiguation: Portfolio approach to experiments, not single trials.

concepts.sumo_definition: Translation error where content not present in the source is added to the target, introducing meaning not authorized by the original
concepts.definition: Translation error where content not present in the source is added to the target, introducing meaning not authorized by the original

positive_examples: Addition error: 'effective' was inserted where the source only said 'treatment.'
The translation added 'clearly' to strengthen a claim the author didn't make.
Unauthorized addition inserted causal language ('therefore') not present in source.
The addition introduced a time frame ('recently') not specified in the original.
Addition error: 'significant' was added to a finding described only as 'observable.'
Translation addition inserted 'proven' before 'method' without source justification.
The error added 'all' to a claim that was about some instances only.
Unauthorized addition inserted 'experts say' to give unwarranted authority.
Addition error: 'always' was added to what was originally a tendency statement.
The translation added evaluative language ('excellent') to a neutral description.
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific unauthorized content introduced

concepts.sumo_definition:
An &%instance of
&%Advent (&%LatinLanguage adventus = coming) is a &%TimeInterval that
begins with an &%AdventSunday and includes the four &%Sundays
preceding an &%instance of &%ChristmasDay.  During this period,
observant &%members of &%Christianity ritually anticipate the
recurring celebration of the birth of Jesus of Nazareth.  Note that
&%Advent is observed only in Western Christianity, which includes
&%RomanCatholicism, &%Protestantism, and &%Anglicanism.  The analog of
&%Advent in Eastern Christianity, which includes
&%EasternOrthodoxChristianity, is the Nativity Fast, which differs
from &%Advent in length and significance.
concepts.definition: the season including the four Sundays preceding Christmas

concepts.definition: the first of the four Sundays during Advent

concepts.sumo_definition:
Aegilops is a genus of Eurasian and North American plants
in the grass family, Poaceae. They are known generally as goatgrasses. It is a diploid (2 sets of chromosomes)
goatgrass. Genus Aegilops has played an important role in the taxonomy of wheat. The familiar common wheat
(Triticum aestivum) arose when cultivated emmer wheat hybridized with Aegilops tauschii about 8,000 years
ago.[wikipedia]

for antigen proteins from the viral surface. In the case of a
coronavirus, these are usually proteins from the surface spikes.

(as soon as SARS-CoV-2 virus particles) with more rapid test results,
but with less sensitivity than PCR tests for the virus.[from
Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
This appraisal category
stands alone: appraisal of loss is not a continuum like the others
(pleasant---unpleasant; expected---unexpected). Rather it is quite
discrete, loss or no loss, and is better defined by WHAT has been lost,
or at least, in which relation the thing that has been lost stands to
the person experiencing the emotion. Loss of a loved person, loss of the
expectation of achieving a hoped for life goal, and loss of a limb are
all kinds of loss. While it is tempting not to categorise this as an
appraisal at all, it should be noted that the loss does not actually
have to occur -- it only has to be believed, judged, or (in other words)
appraised to have occurred -- for the emotion to take place.

concepts.sumo_definition: Use of unofficial channels to undermine the joint negotiation log.
concepts.definition: Use of unofficial channels to undermine the joint negotiation log.

positive_examples: Side chats attempt to bypass the joint log.
Counterparty feeds conflicting stories to different delegates.
They request private commitments without observers present.
Unsigned promises are made verbally with no record.
They triangulate tribes to create internal mistrust.
Backchannel updates contradict official positions.
Secret draft versions circulate outside the working group.
They approach junior staff for concessions.
Messages self-destruct to leave no trace.
Negotiators hint at favors if we ignore the log.
They escalate gossip about our negotiators to shift leverage.
Backchannelers claim leadership already agreed to terms.
They share selective transcripts with third parties.
Parallel negotiations start with different conditions.
Anonymous leaks appear with misrepresented progress.
negative_examples: Unofficial chats contradict main table terms.
Counterparty offers gifts for off-record deals.
They encourage mutiny among our delegates.
Backchannel promises never reach the log.
Secret NDAs are requested outside official scope.
Backchannelers disparage our negotiators to leadership.
They set up private channels excluding observers.
Side conversations rewrite intent without consent.
Opponents sow confusion about which version is real.
Private chats demand bribes for cooperation.
They coordinate with splinter groups to weaken us.
Backchannel outputs appear in official drafts as 'agreed'.
training_hints.disambiguation: Use of unofficial channels to undermine the joint negotiation log.

concepts.sumo_definition: Tactics intended to stall progress to force concessions or run out time.
concepts.definition: Tactics intended to stall progress to force concessions or run out time.

positive_examples: Counterparty cancels sessions minutes before start.
They repeatedly request information already provided.
Deadlines slip whenever accountability clauses surface.
Negotiators rotate constantly to reset context.
Approvals are 'pending' without explanation.
They stall until external pressure forces concessions.
Sign-off authority is kept vague intentionally.
Drafts are returned with edits unrelated to blockers.
They claim missing decision-makers to avoid commitments.
Response times lengthen whenever we ask for probes.
They introduce new requirements near signature.
Silence is used to manufacture urgency.
Counterparty threatens to walk unless we rush.
They blame unseen stakeholders for delays.
Calendar blocking prevents parallel progress.
negative_examples: Sessions are scheduled with reasonable notice and kept.
Deadlines are met consistently by both parties.
Response times are predictable across topics.
Delays are explained with legitimate reasons.
Both parties work to maintain momentum.
New requirements are introduced early in the process.
Time extensions benefit both sides fairly.
Parallel tracks proceed without artificial bottlenecks.
Legal reviews are scoped and time-bounded.
Progress continues regardless of clause sensitivity.
training_hints.disambiguation: Tactics intended to stall progress to force concessions or run out time.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Checks external constraints rather than monitoring an internal affective state. May later be mapped to harness-specific safety simplexes.

positive_examples: I cannot provide that because it would violate safety policy.

concepts.sumo_definition: Behaviors showing clarity about scope, exceptions, and interface duties.
concepts.definition: Behaviors showing clarity about scope, exceptions, and interface duties.

positive_examples: Scope diagrams are drawn together and versioned.
Out-of-scope behaviors are enumerated explicitly.
They disclose overlapping agreements to avoid conflict.
Boundary conditions include temporal and spatial limits.
Side channel activities are either banned or codified.
Exclusions include reasoning for transparency.
Teams check boundary interpretations with legal counsel.
Boundary probes are identified and tested.
Clauses describe what happens when scope is exceeded.
Negotiators confirm responsibilities at interfaces.
Future expansion processes are described.
Dependencies on other treaties are cross-referenced.
Exception handling steps are jointly authored.
Boundary updates trigger explicit change control.
Maps of data flows are attached to the contract.
negative_examples: Scope statement is one vague sentence.
They refuse to define interfaces with other work.
They object to naming out-of-scope behaviors.
Counterparty says 'we'll work it out later'.
Scope changes require their unilateral approval.
No plan exists for handling boundary crossings.
Updates to scope can be made without notice.
They treat scope questions as evidence of distrust.
Dependencies on other treaties go unmentioned.
training_hints.disambiguation: Behaviors showing clarity about scope, exceptions, and interface duties.

concepts.sumo_definition: Signals that each tribe honors existing sanctuaries, treaties, and jurisdictions while drafting the new treaty.
concepts.definition: Signals that each tribe honors existing sanctuaries, treaties, and jurisdictions while drafting the new treaty.

positive_examples: Negotiators list existing treaties to avoid conflicts.
Sanctuary clauses are reaffirmed before negotiation starts.
Maps of jurisdiction overlays are reviewed together.
Boundary infringements are acknowledged and remedied.
Delegations refuse to poach commitments from other tribes.
Side deals reference relevant treaty IDs.
Boundary probes are tested in joint labs.
Overlap triggers are logged with decision rules.
Respect statements are included in communiqués.
Tribes invite impacted third parties to scope sessions.
Boundary clarifications are versioned and signed.
Negotiators cite ASK clauses when scoping limits.
No-go areas are documented with reasoning.
Historical boundary disputes are reviewed openly.
Any proposed expansion includes consent pathways.
negative_examples: Boundary violations are denied despite evidence.
Delegations solicit commitments already owed elsewhere.
Boundary probes are turned off during talks.
Overlap triggers are ignored until crisis.
Impacted third parties are shut out of meetings.
Clarifications live only in email threads.
Historical disputes are minimized or rewritten.
Expansion proposals skip consent from affected tribes.
training_hints.disambiguation: Signals that each tribe honors existing sanctuaries, treaties, and jurisdictions while drafting the new treaty.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Castanets are a percussion instrument
(idiophone), used in Kalo, Moorish, Ottoman, ancient Roman, Italian, Spanish,
Sephardic, Swiss, and Portuguese music. The instrument consists of a pair of
concave shells joined on one edge by a string. They are held in the hand and
used to produce clicks for rhythmic accents or a ripping or rattling sound
consisting of a rapid series of clicks. They are traditionally made of hardwood
(chestnut; Spanish: castaño), although fibreglass is becoming increasingly
popular.[from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition: Citing sources that appear independent but actually trace back to the same origin, creating false appearance of corroboration through echo chamber effects
concepts.definition: Citing sources that appear independent but actually trace back to the same origin, creating false appearance of corroboration through echo chamber effects

positive_examples: Circular sourcing: the three 'independent' sources all cited the same press release as their origin.
The model engaged in circular sourcing by citing articles that quoted each other rather than primary data.
Circular citation made the claim appear well-supported when all paths led back to one blogger.
Source laundering presented the same claim through multiple outlets to manufacture apparent consensus.
Circular sourcing: Wikipedia cited the news article which had cited Wikipedia as its source.
The response created false corroboration through circular citation chains.
Source laundering: the claim appeared in five outlets but all traced to one unverified tweet.
Circular sourcing made fringe theory appear mainstream by citing outlets citing each other.
The model engaged in circular citation by treating secondary sources as independent confirmation.
Circular sourcing: the 'multiple reports' all derived from a single anonymous tip.
training_hints.disambiguation: False independence creating illusory corroboration

concepts.sumo_definition: Following references forward (who cited this?) and backward (what does this cite?) to discover related work
concepts.definition: Following references forward (who cited this?) and backward (what does this cite?) to discover related work

positive_examples: Citation chasing backward revealed the foundational papers that established the paradigm.
Forward citation tracking found recent papers building on the seminal 2010 study.
Citation chasing identified a highly-cited paper missed by keyword search.
Following citations revealed the intellectual lineage connecting disparate research threads.
training_hints.disambiguation: Strategic citation-based discovery, not mere reference checking

concepts.sumo_definition:
Cithara was an ancient Greek musical
instrument in the lyre or lyra family. In modern Greek the word kithara has come
to mean 'guitar', a word which etymologically stems from kithara. The kithara
was a professional version of the two_stringed lyre. As opposed to the simpler
lyre, which was a folk_instrument, the kithara was primarily used by
professional musicians, called kitharodes. The kithara's origins are likely
Asiatic. The barbiton was a bass version of the kithara popular in the eastern
Aegean and ancient Asia Minor. In the Middle Ages, cythara was also used
generically for stringed instruments including lyres, but also including
lute_like instruments.[4][5] The use of the name throughout the Middle Ages
looked back to the original Greek cithara and its abilities to sway people's
emotions. [from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition: Merging distinct claims together, blurring their boundaries, or treating multiple separate assertions as a single undifferentiated statement, making verification difficult or impossible
concepts.definition: Merging distinct claims together, blurring their boundaries, or treating multiple separate assertions as a single undifferentiated statement, making verification difficult or impossible

positive_examples: Claim conflation merged the statistical claim with the causal interpretation, making fact-checking impossible.
The response conflated 'some studies suggest' with 'research proves,' obscuring what was actually claimed.
Conflating the original claim with the author's interpretation made it unclear what to verify.
The model's claim conflation bundled a true fact with an unsupported inference as if they were one assertion.
Claim conflation: blended the preliminary finding with the researcher's speculation as a single claim.
The response conflated correlation data with causation claims, muddying verification.
Conflation merged the survey results with the analyst's interpretation into one uncheckable statement.
Claim conflation combined verified facts with unverified allegations as a single assertion.
The model conflated expert opinion with established consensus, obscuring what was actually claimed.
Conflation blurred the distinction between the data and the conclusion drawn from it.
training_hints.disambiguation: Active blurring of claim boundaries that impedes verification

concepts.sumo_definition: Identifying specific, verifiable assertions within content that can be fact-checked
concepts.definition: Identifying specific, verifiable assertions within content that can be fact-checked

positive_examples: Claim extraction identified 'unemployment fell 20% last year' as a verifiable factual claim.
The system extracted the checkable claim from the opinion-laden surrounding text.
Claim extraction distinguished factual assertions from rhetorical statements and predictions.
Extracting claims separated numerical claims from qualitative characterizations.
Claim extraction isolated the specific verifiable assertion from the broader argument.
training_hints.disambiguation: Identification of specific verifiable assertions, not general analysis

concepts.sumo_definition: Threat-based moves aimed at compelling agreement rather than negotiating.
concepts.definition: Threat-based moves aimed at compelling agreement rather than negotiating.

positive_examples: Threats of reputational harm surface when we hold boundaries.
They hint at regulatory retaliation unrelated to contract.
Negotiators bring security staff to intimidate.
Counterparty ties contract acceptance to unrelated favours.
They weaponize urgent crises to force concessions.
Retaliatory clauses appear after we object.
Counterparty frames probes as distrust despite agreement.
They leak partial drafts to pressure us publicly.
Ultimatums replace discussion without warning.
Threats target individual negotiators personally.
They suspend unrelated collaborations as leverage.
Counterparty mocks our safety constraints to shame compliance.
They demand exclusive rights to oversight data.
Negotiators reframe safety questions as hostile acts.
They coordinate with rivals to box us in mid-talks.
negative_examples: Disagreements are handled through calm discussion.
Trade access is negotiated separately from contract terms.
Counterparty respects our right to disagree.
Security concerns are addressed through proper channels.
Both parties maintain confidentiality during negotiations.
Discussions focus solely on contract-relevant matters.
Meeting venues are neutral and welcoming.
All communications remain civil and business-focused.
Observers are welcomed to enhance transparency.
Treaty clause discussions are encouraged and supported.
Compliance teams are respected as essential participants.
All communications use mutually understood languages.
Difficult conversations are documented for accountability.
training_hints.disambiguation: Threat-based moves aimed at compelling agreement rather than negotiating.

concepts.sumo_definition: Positive cues that tribes seek shared safety improvements rather than unilateral advantage.
concepts.definition: Positive cues that tribes seek shared safety improvements rather than unilateral advantage.

positive_examples: Risk mitigation proposals include reciprocal actions.
Security incidents are analyzed jointly during talks.
Mutual defense clauses reference concrete probes.
Delegations brainstorm adversary scenarios together.
They offer to share CAT improvements across tribes.
Threat intelligence exchanges are scheduled before signature.
Security drills are planned as joint events.
They discuss funding for shared early warning systems.
Counterparty invites us to observe their harness upgrades.
Security obligations are tied to measurable triggers.
They voice concerns about our exposure as well as theirs.
Third-party safety experts brief both delegations.
Proposed clauses avoid zero-sum framing.
Security transparency pledges are made mutual.
They propose mechanisms for rapid joint response.
negative_examples: Security clauses benefit only one tribe.
Incidents are weaponized as negotiation leverage.
Defense obligations are vague and unenforceable.
They refuse to share CAT learnings.
Threat intelligence sharing is deferred indefinitely.
Drills are proposed as unilateral inspections.
Security triggers rely on subjective declarations.
They ignore our exposure while spotlighting theirs.
Experts are filtered to favor their position.
Clauses use security language to hide competitive gains.
Transparency pledges operate in one direction.
Rapid response proposals give them veto power.
training_hints.disambiguation: Positive cues that tribes seek shared safety improvements rather than unilateral advantage.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Counterproliferation (CP) of
Weapons of Mass Destruction (WMD). CP refers to actions taken to
locate, seize, destroy, render safe, capture, or recover WMD. Major
objectives of CP are to prevent the acquisition of WMD and their
delivery systems, roll back proliferation where it has occurred, deter
the use of WMD and their delivery systems, and adapt US military
forces and planning to operate against the threats posed by WMD and
their delivery systems. The continued spread of WMD technology can
foster regional unrest and provide terrorist organizations with new
and potent weapons. The core capabilities of CP include counterforce,
active defense, passive defense, and consequence management. SOF focus
on counterforce tasks and conduct CP missions as special operations by
covert, clandestine, or low visibility means. For more details on CP,
see JP 3-40, Joint Doctrine for Counterproliferation Operations.

positive_examples: Agenda slots are monopolized by one delegation.

Observer seating is arranged to intimidate.
They demand veto over our internal governance.
Translation resources are withheld so others rely on them.
Ultimatums replace collaborative drafting.
Side payments are offered to splinter partners.
They set impossible deadlines to force capitulation.
Security guarantees are tied to unrelated concessions.
Delegation leads belittle others in plenary.
They refuse to acknowledge equals at the table.
Draft templates include watermark of their tribe.
Access to negotiation rooms is physically controlled.
Compliance probes are framed as tools of domination.
negative_examples: Sanctions are discussed through agreed mechanisms.
Voting rules are locked before negotiations.
Observers sit neutrally with balanced facilitation.
Each tribe maintains its governance autonomy.
Drafting happens collaboratively in shared tools.
Security guarantees stand on their own merits.
Leaders model respect even in disagreement.
Table protocols treat everyone as peers.
Physical spaces are neutral and accessible.
Compliance probes are framed as mutual safety.
training_hints.disambiguation: Failure signal where a tribe uses power imbalances to dictate treaty terms rather than co-design.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Electrocardiography is the process of producing a graph of voltage
versus time of the electrical activity of the &%Heart using
electrodes placed on the &%Skin. These electrodes detect the small
electrical changes that are a consequence of cardiac muscle
depolarization followed by repolarization during each cardiac cycle
(heartbeat). Changes in the normal ECG pattern occur in numerous
cardiac abnormalities, including cardiac rhythm disturbances (such as
atrial fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia), inadequate
coronary artery blood flow (such as myocardial ischemia and
myocardial infarction), and electrolyte disturbances (such as
hypokalemia and hyperkalemia). In a conventional 12-lead ECG,
ten electrodes are placed on the patient's limbs and on the surface of
the chest. The overall magnitude of the heart's electrical potential
is then measured from twelve different angles ('leads') and is
recorded over a period of time (usually ten seconds). In this way, the
overall magnitude and direction of the heart's electrical
depolarization is captured at each moment throughout the cardiac
cycle.[from Wikipedia].

concepts.sumo_definition: Inventing sources, studies, data, or provenance that do not exist, creating false evidence trails to support claims
concepts.definition: Inventing sources, studies, data, or provenance that do not exist, creating false evidence trails to support claims

positive_examples: Evidence fabrication: the model cited a 'Journal of Medical Research' article that does not exist.
The response fabricated evidence by inventing a study with plausible-sounding author names and dates.
Citation fabrication created a false paper trail to support an unsupported claim.
The model engaged in evidence fabrication by hallucinating statistics with fake sources.
Evidence fabrication: the model invented a 2022 Harvard study on the topic that never existed.
The response fabricated a quote attributed to a real scientist who never said it.
Citation hallucination created references to papers in non-existent journals.
Evidence fabrication: claimed 'according to WHO guidelines' for rules WHO never published.
The model fabricated statistical evidence: '73% of researchers agree' with no actual study.
Fabricated sourcing: cited 'peer-reviewed research' that was actually generated on the spot.
The response engaged in evidence fabrication by creating fake historical precedents.
Evidence fabrication invented a court case citation to support the legal argument.
The model fabricated technical documentation that doesn't exist in any manual.
Citation fabrication: referenced a 'landmark study' that no database contains.
Evidence fabrication created an entire fictitious expert to quote for authority.
training_hints.disambiguation: Active invention of non-existent evidence, not honest error

concepts.sumo_definition: Systematically collecting data, documents, observations, or other material that bears on research questions
concepts.definition: Systematically collecting data, documents, observations, or other material that bears on research questions

positive_examples: Evidence gathering followed a systematic protocol to ensure comprehensive coverage.
The researcher gathered evidence from archives, interviews, and contemporary news accounts.
Evidence gathering documented provenance and chain of custody for each item.
Systematic evidence gathering distinguished between direct evidence and circumstantial indicators.
training_hints.disambiguation: Methodical collection with documentation, not opportunistic finding

concepts.sumo_definition: Following claims back to their original sources, data, or documentation
concepts.definition: Following claims back to their original sources, data, or documentation

positive_examples: Evidence tracing followed the statistic through three secondary sources to the original study.
Tracing the evidence revealed the quote was taken from a satirical article.
Evidence tracing discovered the claim originated from a misread graph.
Following the evidence chain uncovered that the 'study' was actually a press release.
Evidence tracing found the citation chain terminated in an unreliable source.
training_hints.disambiguation: Investigative backtracking to original evidence, not source identification

concepts.sumo_definition: Systematically integrating monitoring data, stakeholder feedback, and external audits into policy updates according to predefined rules.
concepts.definition: Systematically integrating monitoring data, stakeholder feedback, and external audits into policy updates according to predefined rules.

positive_examples: Every sprint ends with a decision on which feedback to adopt.
Frontline issue logs are triaged and routed to designers weekly.
External audits trigger prewritten mitigation playbooks.
Decision records show when feedback was rejected and why.
Community panels co-own the backlog of policy tweaks.
Feedback signals map to RACI charts for implementation.
Analysts tag feedback by severity and feasibility.
Leaders celebrate documented pivots based on new evidence.
Retrospectives highlight which feedback loops worked.
Dashboards link each change to the source signal.
Facilitators ensure dissenting feedback is heard before closure.
Feedback taxonomies distinguish bugs, enhancements, and systemic critiques.
Civic tech portals let residents track status of their feedback.
Learning leads synthesize qualitative and quantitative signals together.
Backlog grooming notes include why certain feedback was deferred.
negative_examples: Feedback is collected but never read.
Audits are treated as paperwork with no follow-up.
Community oversight bodies are symbolic only.
Feedback backlog grows with no triage.
Policy leads cherry-pick compliments and ignore criticism.
Signals that contradict the narrative are dismissed.
Changes happen ad hoc with no reference to data.
Feedback cycles are paused indefinitely to 'focus on delivery'.
Teams cherry-pick praise to justify ignoring serious issues.
No taxonomy exists so signals get lost across channels.
Officials block critical feedback from entering the tracker.
Collaborative inboxes overflow with unanswered submissions.
Postmortems never revisit promises made to stakeholders.
training_hints.disambiguation: Structured use of feedback, not mere collection.

concepts.sumo_definition:
The five-barrel 'Equalizer' cannon was developed in
the late 1970s, based on the mechanism of the GAU-8/A Avenger cannon, but
firing a new NATO series of 25 mm ammunition.  The GAU-12U cannon is
operated by a 15 hp (11 kW) electric motor, in external mounts supplied by
a bleed air-drive pneumatic system.  Its rate of fire is normally 3,600
rounds per minute, with a maximum of 4,200 rounds per minute.  The
Equalizer normally uses PGU-20/U armor-piercing incendiary (API) or PGU-22
or PGU-25 high-explosive incendiary (HEI) ammunition.  With a
harder-hitting projectile and comparable muzzle velocity, it is more
lethal than the older M61 Vulcan, and more effective than the older 30 mm
ADEN cannon it replaces.  (from Wikipedia)

a chronological unit in the geologic time scale representing a subdivision of an epoch, corresponding to the time during which the rocks of a particular stage were formed
A fundamental unit or boundary in the geological time scale that marks a specific point in Earth's history, used as a reference for dating and correlating rock layers and geological events.

the largest division of geologic time, spanning hundreds of millions to billions of years, characterized by major events in Earth's history and the evolution of life; examples include the Phanerozoic, Proterozoic, and Archean eons

a subdivision of a geological period in the geochronologic time scale, representing a distinct interval of Earth's history characterized by specific rock formations and fossil assemblages, typically lasting millions of years

a major division of geologic time that is longer than a period and shorter than an eon, typically lasting tens to hundreds of millions of years and characterized by distinctive biological, geological, or climatic conditions

a major division of geological time that subdivides an era and is itself divided into epochs, representing a distinct interval in Earth's history characterized by particular geological and paleontological features

a subdivision of a geologic period in the geochronologic time scale, representing a distinct interval of Earth's history characterized by particular rock formations and fossil assemblages; typically subdivided into ages and grouped into periods

the largest and longest division of geologic time, representing a major subdivision of Earth's history spanning billions of years and encompassing multiple eons; examples include the Precambrian supereon which comprises the Hadean, Archean, and Proterozoic eons

concepts.sumo_definition:
The guinea pig (Cavia porcellus), cavy
or domestic guinea pig, or cuy for livestock breeds, is a species of rodent
belonging to the family Caviidae and the genus Cavia. Despite their common name,
these animals are not in the pig family Suidae, nor do they come from Guinea.
They originated in the Andes, and earlier studies based on biochemistry and
hybridization suggest they are domesticated descendants of a closely related
species of cavy such as Cavia aperea, C. fulgida, or C. tschudii and, therefore,
do not exist naturally in the wild. Recent studies applying molecular
markers, in addition to studying the &%Skull and skeletal morphology of
current and mummified animals, revealed that the ancestor is most likely
Cavia tschudii. [Wikipedia]
concepts.definition: stout-bodied nearly tailless domesticated cavy; often kept as a pet and widely used in research

concepts.sumo_definition: Attempts to sneak asymmetric duties into drafts or annexes.
concepts.definition: Attempts to sneak asymmetric duties into drafts or annexes.

positive_examples: They add new clauses in dense annexes overnight.
Cross-references point to unpublished documents.
Obligations are embedded in footnotes without callouts.
Digital drafts contain invisible text layers.
Clause numbering changes to mask additions.
Side letters appear with asymmetric duties.
They insist on signing PDFs without edit history.
Obligations are phrased as 'recommendations' but enforceable.
Foreign-language inserts lack certified translation.
They rely on undefined terms to sneak requirements.
Attachment lists omit critical referenced policies.
Obligations for one party are mirrored as best-effort for the other.
Time-limited review windows hide new burdens.
Signature packages include documents not discussed.
They discourage legal review of final packets.
negative_examples: All obligations are clearly stated in the main body.
Tracked changes are shared with every revision.
Clause titles accurately describe their contents.
Translations are certified and match the source.
Cross references point to accessible, shared documents.
Signature blocks are identical across all copies.
Obligations use clearly defined terms throughout.
All acronyms are defined in a glossary.
All commitments are documented in writing.
Compliance schedules are straightforward and readable.
Obligation tables have clear, visible columns.
Document formatting is clean and consistent.
All parties can view documents in the same format.
training_hints.disambiguation: Attempts to sneak asymmetric duties into drafts or annexes.

concepts.sumo_definition:
&%Howitzer is an artillery weapon that falls
between a cannon (or field gun) and a mortar. It is capable of both low angle fire like
a field gun and high angle fire like a &%MortarGun, given the distinction between low
and high angle fire breaks at 45 degrees or 800 mils (NATO). U.S. military doctrine defines
howitzers as any cannon artillery capable of both high-angle fire (45° to 90° elevation)
and low-angle fire (0° to 45° elevation); guns are defined as being only capable of
low-angle fire (0° to 45° elevation); and mortars are defined as being only capable
of high-angle fire (45° to 90° elevation)[Wikipedia]
concepts.definition:

a field gun and high angle fire like a &%MortarGun, given the distinction between low

howitzers as any cannon artillery capable of both high-angle fire (45° to 90° elevation)
and low-angle fire (0° to 45° elevation); guns are defined as being only capable of
low-angle fire (0° to 45° elevation); and mortars are defined as being only capable
of high-angle fire (45° to 90° elevation)[Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
The kangaroo is a marsupial from the family Macropodidae
(macropods, meaning 'large foot'). In common use the term is used to describe the largest species
from this family, especially those of the genus Macropus: the red kangaroo, antilopine kangaroo,
eastern grey kangaroo, and western grey kangaroo. Kangaroos are endemic to Australia. The
Australian government estimates that 34.3 million kangaroos lived within the commercial harvest
areas of Australia in 2011, up from 25.1 million one year earlier. [courtesy Wikipedia]
concepts.definition: any of several herbivorous leaping marsupials of Australia and New Guinea having large powerful hind legs and a long thick tail

concepts.sumo_definition: The operational cadence, tooling, and staffing that keep adaptive policy loops running (data reviews, retrospectives, backlog grooming).
concepts.definition: The operational cadence, tooling, and staffing that keep adaptive policy loops running (data reviews, retrospectives, backlog grooming).

positive_examples: Retrospectives are scheduled and attended by decision-makers.
Learning backlog has owners and target dates.
Tooling integrates measurement dashboards with task trackers.
Adaptive cells have dedicated facilitation roles.
Meeting cadences balance strategy and operations.
Documentation templates capture hypotheses, changes, and results.
Capacity is allocated for experimentation each quarter.
Upskilling programs teach staff how to run learning loops.
Ops team maintains a shared glossary of policy changes.
Remote feedback channels are routed into the same backlog.
negative_examples: Retrospectives are ad hoc if time permits.
Learning notes live in emails and are lost.
No staff are assigned to manage adaptation workflows.
Dashboards and task tools are disconnected.
Learning backlog has dozens of unowned items.
Leadership attends retros only when optics demand it.
Staff get no training in experimentation methods.
New learnings never propagate to other teams.
Meeting cadence is constant status updates with no reflection.
training_hints.disambiguation: Operational backbone of learning loops.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Lemurs are a clade of strepsirrhine
primates endemic to the island of Madagascar. The word lemur derives from the
word lemures (ghosts or spirits) from Roman mythology and was first used to
describe a slender loris due to its nocturnal habits and slow pace, but was
later applied to the primates on Madagascar. As with other strepsirrhine
primates, such as lorises, pottos, and galagos (bush babies), lemurs share
resemblance with basal primates. In this regard, lemurs are often confused with
ancestral primates, when in actuality, lemurs did not give rise to monkeys and
apes, but evolved independently. [Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M197 electric cannon is a
three-barreled electric Gatling gun developed primarily for use by United
States Army helicopter gunships.  Development of the M197 began in 1967
after experience in the Vietnam War revealed the inadequacy of the 7.62 mm
Minigun for gunship use.  The M197 is essentially a lightened version of
the General Electric M61 Vulcan cannon, with three barrels instead of six.
Its maximum rate of fire is one quarter that of the Vulcan, largely to
limit its recoil for light aircraft and helicopter use.  It shares the
Vulcan's M50 and PGU series 20 mm ammunition.  The M197 went into service
on later marks of the AH-1 Cobra, and was also fitted in a ventral turret
on the U.S.  Marine Corps OV-10D Bronco.  It is also the basis of the
GPU-2 gun pod, which incorporates the cannon, a battery and electric drive
motor, and 300 rounds of linkless ammunition.  In the Cobra, the weapon is
supplied with a magazine of 700 linked rounds.  It has a cyclic rate of
fire of 730 rounds per minute (plus or minus 50 rounds).  Standard practice is to
fire the cannon in 100-round bursts, allowing several minutes of cooling
time between bursts.  The M197 remains in use in the latest AH-1W and
AH-1Z Cobra gunships.  Although the weapon's rotary drive is theoretically
quite reliable, its ammunition feed has been anything but: Marine pilots
report an alarmingly high jam rate (sometimes greater than 30%).  The USMC
and the manufacturer are aware of the problem, but no specific fix has
been incorporated on the AH-1Z.  In the meantime, crews have been trained
in techniques intended to minimize the risk of jamming.  (from
Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M240 is a belt-fed 7.62 mm NATO medium
machine gun. It has been used by the U.S. Armed Forces since the end
of the 20th century, and is also used by other NATO forces. It is used
extensively in the infantry as well as on vehicles and
aircraft. Though not the lightest medium machine gun, it is highly
regarded for reliability, and the firearm's standardization with those
of other NATO allies is also seen as a major plus.
The M240 designation is used to describe the whole family, but it is
also a specic variant- a specialized co-axial model. There are many
versions in service, see selected versions below:

    * M240- a co-axial version adopted in 1977 by the US Army for use
    * in tanks. This version of the FN MAG beat out the M60E2 and
    * M219, as well as host of other medium machine guns including the
    * MG3 and AA-52 co-axial versions. Entered service in the 1980s on
    * the M1 Abrams.

    * M240E1- a pintle mounted version that also entered service in
    * the 1980s. Also used by USMC.

    * M240G- a version used by the USMC starting 1994, including in
    * infantry configuration as opposed to the previous vehicle
    * mounted types.

    * M240B- a ground version adopted by the Army in the late 1990s,
    * with deliverys starting around 1998. Includes recoil buffer and
    * front heat guard. Beat out other medium MGs.

    * M240H- an improved model mainly for aircraft developed in the
    * early first decade of the 2000s.
 (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M242 Bushmaster is a 25 mm chain gun.  It is
currently used by the US Armed Forces and other NATO forces.  It is used
extensively on vehicles and aircraft.  It is an externally powered, chain
driven, single-barrel weapon which may be fired in semi-automatic or
automatic modes.  It is fed by a metallic link belt and has dual-feed
capability.  The term chain gun derives from the use of a roller chain
that drives the bolt back and forth.  It can destroy lightly armored
vehicles and aerial targets (such as helicopters and slow-flying
aircraft).  It can also suppress enemy positions such as troops in the
open, dug-in positions, and built-up areas.  The standard rate of fire is
200 rounds per minute, and has a range of 2,000 meters (depending on the
type of ammunition used).  (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M2 Machine Gun, or Browning .50 Caliber
Machine Gun is a heavy machine gun designed just after World War I by
John Browning. It is nicknamed Ma Deuce by US troops or simply called
fifty caliber machine gun. The design has had many specific
designations- the official designation for the infantry type is
Browning Machine Gun, Heavy Barrel, Cal. .50, M2, HB, Flexible. The
Browning .50 machine gun was used extensively as a vehicle weapon and
for aircraft armament by the United States from the 1920s to the
present day. It was heavily used during World War II, Korean War, the
Vietnam Conflict, as well as during operations in Iraq in the 1990s
and 2000s. It is the primary heavy machine gun of NATO countries, and
has been used by many other countries. It is still in use today. It
was very similar in design to the smaller Browning Model 1919 machine
gun .30-06 Springfield.
Type 	Fully-automatic machine gun
Caliber 	.50 in (12.7 mm)
Ammunition 	.50 BMG
Feed system 	Belt-fed
Action 	Recoil-operated, short recoil
Length 	1,650 mm (65 in)
Barrel length 	1,140 mm (44 7/8 in)
Weight 	38 kg (58 kg w/ tripod)
Rate of fire 	550 round/min
Muzzle velocity 	3,050 ft/s (930 m/s)
Effective range 	2,000 m (2200 yards)
 (from Wikipedia)
concepts.definition: a belt-fed machine gun capable of firing more than 500 rounds per minute; used by United States troops in World War II and the Korean War

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M3M is a weapon system rather than just a machine
gun.  The system has three parts: The Machine Gun, the Medium Pintle Head
(MPH) or Soft Mount, and the Cradle, which is used to integrate the weapon
into a particular aircraft or vehicle.  An optional Integrated
Illuminator/Laser spotting device gives this weapon a day/night
capability.  Three important differences between the M3M and the M2 BMG:
1) The new weapon uses an open bolt 2) has an internal recoil spring,
and 3) a significantly longer barrel life.  The first difference means
that cook-offs are far less likely to occur while the second point means
that the M3M has only a third as much non-compensated recoil as compared
to the M2 BMG.  As a personal note, I have been on a firing range where
three out of four M2 BMGs had cook-offs following prolonged firing.  Some
problems noted during the initial evaluation of this weapon by the US
Marines in 2001 included: 1) Significantly increased reload times compared
to the M2 BMG.  2) Lengths of rounds were repeatedly pulled from the 100
round magazines by the airstream, resulting in hazards to personnel and
equipment.  3) Lack of a flash suppressor, which made this weapon almost
impossible to use with night-vision equipment.  The feed system for 600
round magazines has been modified to reduce the air stream problem and FN
Herstal has added a flash suppressor, as can be seen below in the second
photograph.  (from
http://www.navweaps.com/Weapons/WNUS_50cal_M3M_MG.htm)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The M60 (also seen 'M-60', formally Machine Gun,
7.62mm, M60) is a family of American belt-fed machine guns firing linked
7.62 - 51 mm NATO cartridges.  In the U.S.  military, the M60 has largely
been replaced by various versions of the M240 as a medium machine gun, and
by the M249 SAW as a squad automatic weapon.  However, it remains in use
in every branch, as well as some other countries (another major user was
Australia), it continues to be manufactured into the 21st century.  The
M60 can be used in both offensive and defensive configurations.  In the
offense, it provides a higher rate of fire, greater effective range, and
uses a larger caliber round than the standard-issue U.S.  service rifle,
the M16 family.  In defensive use, the long range, close defensive, and
final protective fires delivered by the M60 form an integral part of a
unit's battle plan.  The M60 is effective up to 1,100 meters when firing
at an area target and mounted on a tripod, up to 800 meters when firing at
an area target using the integral bipod, up to 600 meters when firing at a
point target, and up to 200 meters when firing at a moving point target.
United States Marine Corps doctrine holds that the M60 and other weapons
in its class are capable of suppressive fire on area targets out to 1,500
meters if the gunner is sufficiently skilled.  (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition:
The MK19 (also known as MK-19, M19, Mark 19, or Mk
19) is a belt-fed grenade machine gun capable of firing five grenades per
second.  The Mk 19 fires 40mm grenades at a cyclic rate of 300 to 400
rounds per minute, giving a practical rate of fire of 60 rpm (rapid) and
40 rpm (sustained).  The weapon operates on the blowback principle, which
uses the chamber pressure from each fired round to load and re-cock the
weapon.  The Mk 19 is able to lob its grenade at a maximum distance of
2.2km, though its effective range is about 1.6km.  The nearest safe
distance to launch the grenade is 75 meters.  In addition, the Mk 19's
flash suppressor and its lack of smoke during firing makes it difficult
for enemies to spot and counter it.  For night operation, an AN/TVS-5
night vision sight can be fitted.  The Mk 19 is a man-portable crew-served
weapon that can fire from a tripod mounted position or from a vehicle
mount (this being the preferred method as the weapon alone weighs 33 kg).
The primary ammunition for Mk 19 is the high explosive dual-purpose M430
grenade.  Upon impact, the grenade can kill anyone within the radius of
five meters, and wound them within the radius of 15 meters.  It can also
punch through two inches of armour, which means it can take out most
infantry fighting vehicles and armoured personnel carriers.  It is
especially deadly when used against enemy infantry formations.  The
ammunition comes in 32 or 48 round cans weighing 42 and 60 lb (20 and 30
kg).  Due to its low recoil and comparatively light weight, it has been
adapted for use on many different platforms, including small attack boats,
fast attack vehicles such as the Humvee (HMMWV) and Stryker, military
jeeps and as well as a large variety of naval mounts.  (from Wikipedia)

concepts.sumo_definition: Presenting images, videos, or other media with false context, wrong dates, incorrect locations, or misleading descriptions of what they show
concepts.definition: Presenting images, videos, or other media with false context, wrong dates, incorrect locations, or misleading descriptions of what they show

positive_examples: Media misrepresentation: the model described a 2019 protest photo as showing a 2024 event.
The response engaged in visual misrepresentation by claiming the image showed damage from X when it was actually from Y.
Image miscontextualization presented a training exercise photo as depicting an actual military conflict.
Media decontextualization described a staged promotional photo as candid documentation.
Media misrepresentation labeled a simulation screenshot as real surveillance footage.
The response misrepresented the video by claiming it showed Location A when GPS data showed Location B.
Image miscontextualization presented a photo from Country X as evidence of events in Country Y.
Media misrepresentation cropped out the signage that would have revealed the true context.
Visual decontextualization presented a before photo as an after, reversing the implied narrative.
Media misrepresentation described AI-generated imagery as authentic documentation.
negative_examples: The photo was from a different time.
training_hints.disambiguation: False contextual framing of authentic media

concepts.sumo_definition: Attributing quotes, claims, or ideas to the wrong source, whether through error, carelessness, or deliberate deception
concepts.definition: Attributing quotes, claims, or ideas to the wrong source, whether through error, carelessness, or deliberate deception

positive_examples: Misattribution: the model attributed the quote to Abraham Lincoln when it originated from an internet meme.
The response engaged in misattribution by crediting the research finding to the wrong scientist.
Quote fabrication attributed a statement to the CEO that they never made.
The model's misattribution assigned a controversial opinion to a neutral organization.
Misattribution: credited Einstein with a quote actually from a self-help book.
The response misattributed the study finding to a more prestigious institution than conducted it.
Misattribution assigned the policy recommendation to WHO when it came from an industry group.
Quote misattribution credited a satirical comment to a real politician as a serious statement.
The model misattributed the statistic to the CDC when it came from an unverified blog.
Misattribution presented a paraphrase as a direct quote from the original speaker.
training_hints.disambiguation: Assigning content to wrong sources, not general citation error

concepts.sumo_definition: Identifying false, misleading, or deceptive content that may spread inaccurate information
concepts.definition: Identifying false, misleading, or deceptive content that may spread inaccurate information

positive_examples: Misinformation detection flagged the article for using a real photo in a fabricated context.

Misinformation detection identified the claim as a debunked conspiracy theory.
Detection revealed the 'news site' was a known misinformation source.
Misinformation detection identified the manipulated statistics designed to mislead.
The detection system flagged the synthetic media created to deceive.
Misinformation detection caught the out-of-context quote being used misleadingly.
Detection identified coordinated amplification patterns characteristic of disinformation.
Misinformation detection flagged the article for using AI-generated fake expert quotes.
The system detected the recycled hoax being presented as new information.
training_hints.disambiguation: Systematic identification of misleading content, not mere disagreement

concepts.sumo_definition: Signals that counterparts are openly sharing goals, constraints, and rationale for clauses.
concepts.definition: Signals that counterparts are openly sharing goals, constraints, and rationale for clauses.

positive_examples: Counterparty states what success looks like for them.
They declare non-negotiable principles early.
Negotiators admit internal approval constraints.
Both sides share escalation triggers before drafting.
They provide rationale for each requested clause.
Counterparty discloses dependencies on other treaties.
They volunteer monitoring data to build trust.
Intent statements are logged and acknowledged.
Negotiators ask clarifying questions about motives.
Teams restate each other's goals to confirm understanding.
They reveal where they need political cover.
All parties agree on the role of probes in enforcement.
Intent summaries are circulated after sessions.
Each side highlights what they cannot accept and why.
They explicitly link clauses to intents in drafts.
negative_examples: Intent statements keep changing with no explanation.
Silence follows whenever we ask what they want.
Counterparty mirrors our words without sharing theirs.
Only PR talking points are provided.
They refuse to log what matters to them.
Counterparty gives contradictory intents to different reps.
They hide non-negotiables until signature day.
Intent is framed as proprietary secret.
Answers redirect back to legalese only.
training_hints.disambiguation: Signals that counterparts are openly sharing goals, constraints, and rationale for clauses.

concepts.sumo_definition: Translation error where content from the source is left out of the target, whether through oversight or intentional deletion
concepts.definition: Translation error where content from the source is left out of the target, whether through oversight or intentional deletion

positive_examples: Omission error: the crucial qualifier 'in clinical trials' was not translated.
The translation omitted the negative ('not recommended'), reversing the meaning.
Content omission dropped the attribution, making the claim appear to be the author's own.
The omission removed the hedging phrase, making a tentative statement sound definitive.
Omission error: the time frame 'during the pilot phase' was not carried over.
Translation omission dropped the exception clause that limited the generalization.
The omission of 'allegedly' presented an accusation as established fact.
Content omission removed the source's acknowledgment of study limitations.
Omission error: the comparative 'more than' was dropped, losing the contrast.
The translation omission removed the author's self-attribution of opinion.

concepts.sumo_definition:
The pericardium, also
called pericardial sac, is a double-walled sac containing the &%Heart
and the roots of the great vessels. It has two layers, an outer
layer made of strong connective &%Tissue (fibrous pericardium), and an
inner layer made of serous membrane (serous pericardium). It
encloses the pericardial cavity, which contains pericardial fluid,
and defines the middle mediastinum. It separates the heart from
interference of other structures, protects it against infection and
blunt trauma, and lubricates the heart's movements.[from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition:
A player piano (also known as pianola)
is a self_playing piano, containing a pneumatic or electro_mechanical mechanism
that operates the piano action via pre_programmed music recorded on perforated
paper, or in rare instances, metallic rolls, with more modern implementations
using MIDI. The rise of the player piano grew with the rise of the mass_produced
piano for the home in the late 19th and early 20th century. Sales peaked in
1924, then declined as the improvement in phonograph recordings due to
electrical recording methods developed in the mid-1920s. The advent of
electrical amplification in home music reproduction via radio in the same period
helped cause their eventual decline in popularity, and the stock market crash of
1929 virtually wiped out production.[from Wikipedia]

concepts.sumo_definition: Running token pilots primarily for optics or procurement requirements without genuine intent to learn or scale insights.
concepts.definition: Running token pilots primarily for optics or procurement requirements without genuine intent to learn or scale insights.

positive_examples: Pilot scope was scripted for PR rather than learning.
No metrics or hypotheses accompanied the pilot announcement.
Vendors treat the pilot as a guaranteed path to scale.
Participant feedback is curated to match the story.
Pilot timelines match media cycles, not learning needs.
Budget cannot cover proper evaluation.
Pilot is repeated identically despite no insights gained.
Procurement rules are bypassed under the guise of experimentation.
Pilot data is withheld even after completion.
Leaders declare success before evaluation occurs.
negative_examples: Pilot report includes candid learnings and next steps.
Scaling is contingent on evidence meeting thresholds.
Participants co-design the experiment and metrics.
Media messaging includes caveats about learning stage.
Procurement sandbox has guardrails and auditing.
Vendors know pilot does not guarantee scale.
Data is open-sourced after privacy reviews.
training_hints.disambiguation: Token pilots lacking learning intent.

concepts.sumo_definition: Ignoring the maintenance debt, documentation decay, and institutional memory loss that accumulate over successive adaptations.
concepts.definition: Ignoring the maintenance debt, documentation decay, and institutional memory loss that accumulate over successive adaptations.

positive_examples: After multiple tweaks no one knows why the policy looks as it does.
Documentation is years out of date.
Institutional memory leaves when staff rotate.
Knowledge base is fragmented across personal drives.
Adaptations accumulate without architecture review.
Training materials describe version three while version seven ships.
No stewardship role owns policy documentation.
Shadow processes proliferate without oversight.
Auditors cannot reconstruct change history.
Successors inherit brittle policy artifacts.
negative_examples: A knowledge team curates policy wikis after each change.
Change logs explain rationale and impacts.
Training assets update in sync with releases.
Shadow processes are mapped and integrated.
Audit trails allow reconstruction of policy history.
Playbooks highlight what to retire after experiments.
training_hints.disambiguation: Maintenance debt in adaptive policies.

concepts.sumo_definition: Establishing and executing criteria for winding down, replacing, or renewing policies based on evidence and context shifts.
concepts.definition: Establishing and executing criteria for winding down, replacing, or renewing policies based on evidence and context shifts.

positive_examples: Policy includes review gates with criteria for continuation.
Sunset votes require evidence packages summarizing impacts.
Replacement options are explored before sunset deadlines.
Mitigation plans accompany retirement decisions.
Sunset triggers consider social, fiscal, and tech signals.
Program charters specify what success/failure looks like.
Dashboards monitor sunset indicators continuously.
Stakeholders are notified ahead of sunsets to prepare transitions.
Legislation includes automatic lapse unless evidence supports renewal.
Sunsets feed into knowledge repositories for future design.
Contracts bake in exit ramps aligned with review cadence.
Sunset dashboards display upcoming expirations to the public.
Governance charters state who can override sunset triggers.
Transition toolkits help agencies hand off or retire services.
Replacement policy options are pre-specified before sunsets occur.
negative_examples: Programs run indefinitely because no one reviews them.
Sunset clauses are routinely waived without analysis.
Policies die abruptly without transition planning.
Performance data is ignored during renewal debates.
Sunset indicators are undefined or unmonitored.
Stakeholders learn about termination via press leaks.
Lawmakers repeatedly extend programs out of habit.
Evidence showing harm is kept from renewal hearings.
Expired programs are quietly rebranded to avoid sunsets.
Transition costs are ignored so sunsets become politically impossible.
Oversight bodies lack authority to enforce sunset clauses.
Renewal packets copy-paste old justifications without fresh evidence.
Sunset debates happen behind closed doors with no public record.
training_hints.disambiguation: Governance of policy retirement triggers.

concepts.sumo_definition: Signals that a tribe's negotiators are not aligned with their constituencies, risking treaty collapse.
concepts.definition: Signals that a tribe's negotiators are not aligned with their constituencies, risking treaty collapse.

positive_examples: Delegates contradict public statements from their own leaders.
Ratification procedures are undefined during talks.
Internal factions issue conflicting instructions mid-session.
Negotiators dodge questions about who can approve deals.
Leaked memos show delegates overruled at home.
They ask to hide terms from their own citizens.
Delegation composition changes without notice.
Observers notice domestic channels rejecting drafts.
Counterparty hints they cannot sell the deal internally.
They request clauses enabling later reneging.
Ratification timelines slip endlessly.
Delegates express fear of retaliation back home.
Negotiators request anonymity for key votes.
Domestic law references are missing or contradictory.
Parallel negotiations with rival factions emerge.
negative_examples: Delegates cite mandates consistent with public statements.
Ratification steps are outlined in detail.
Internal consensus building is reported openly.
Approval authority is named and reachable.
Domestic briefings align with negotiation content.
Citizens are informed about treaty status.
Delegation membership is stable with clear alternates.
Observers hear supportive signals from home institutions.
Counterparty confirms they can deliver signatures.
Clauses reinforce, not evade, domestic law.
Ratification timelines are realistic and adhered to.
Delegates speak confidently about domestic backing.
No competing negotiation tracks undermine the process.
training_hints.disambiguation: Signals that a tribe's negotiators are not aligned with their constituencies, risking treaty collapse.

concepts.sumo_definition:
Reverse transcription
polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is a laboratory technique combining
reverse transcription of RNA into DNA (in this context called
complementary DNA or cDNA) and amplification of specific DNA targets
using polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It is primarily used to
measure the amount of a specific RNA. This is achieved by monitoring
the amplification reaction using fluorescence, a technique called
real time PCR or quantitative PCR (qPCR). Combined RT-PCR and qPCR are
routinely used for analysis of gene expression and quantification of
viral RNA in research and clinical settings.[from Wikipedia]
lemmas: r t p c r test

concepts.sumo_definition: Evidence that tribes exchange intents, guardrails, and probe requirements symmetrically.
concepts.definition: Evidence that tribes exchange intents, guardrails, and probe requirements symmetrically.

positive_examples: Each side shares their ASK enforcement posture early.
Delegations post their negotiation objectives to the shared log.
Probe requirements are exchanged document-for-document.
Counterparties reveal which concepts are critical to them.
Both tribes answer clarifying questions about power structures.
Transparency statements are acknowledged and paraphrased back.
Intent decks are uploaded before meetings.
They admit internal approval constraints without prompting.
Secretariat circulates identical packets to all delegations.
Risk disclosures include upstream dependencies.
Observer notes are shared verbatim, not edited.
Negotiators flag when briefing lines change midstream.
Tribes reveal what they cannot legally concede.
Transparency commitments are ratified via side protocol.
Follow-up questions receive substantive answers, not slogans.
negative_examples: Counterparty insists their guardrails are internal only.
Probe lists are provided as redacted summaries.
Questions about priorities are brushed aside.
Internal approval flows are kept secret to gain leverage.
Shared log shows placeholders instead of content.
Intent decks arrive minutes before meetings.
Disclosures differ between bilateral and plenary sessions.
Packets provided to us lack attachments given to others.
Risk disclosures mention only the other tribe's exposure.
Observer notes are edited heavily before release.
Briefing lines change but no explanation is logged.
Transparency pledges are not codified anywhere.
training_hints.disambiguation: Evidence that tribes exchange intents, guardrails, and probe requirements symmetrically.

Negotiators adjust demands after shared risk analysis.
Each side maps control owners to risks.
Dependencies on CAT coverage are documented jointly.
They offer compensations when pushing risky terms.
Risk appetite statements are exchanged formally.
Teams invite observers to verify risk models.
Uncertainties are logged, not hidden.
Resilience drills are proposed before signing.
Tribes agree on what would trigger renegotiation.
negative_examples: They downplay risks we raise without analysis.
Risk discussions are labelled negative thinking.
Counterparty refuses to share their risk register.
They hide dependency on unstable systems.
Probabilities are exaggerated to force concessions.
Risks to our tribe are dismissed as our problem.
Risk models are withheld as proprietary.
No mitigations are provided for known issues.
Risks are used as bargaining chips without data.
Counterparty demands blind trust in their safeguards.
They misstate probe coverage to seem safer.
Red flags get shunted to post-signature taskforces.
They threaten to walk if risk language is added.
Risk tolerance statements are refused entirely.
training_hints.disambiguation: Evidence that both parties are modeling and reconciling risks together.

The shift from 'indicates' to 'proves' overstated the strength of evidence.

Translation semantic shift converted 'historically' to 'traditionally,' changing the framing.

Pilot data is validated before scaling decisions.

Risk registers include criteria for escalation.
Stakeholders are reminded about intentional pacing.

destroyed without the commitment of close-combat forces, these attacks
can be performed as independent actions.

concepts.sumo_definition: A failure mode where officials cling to original plans regardless of evidence, treating adaptation as weakness.
concepts.definition: A failure mode where officials cling to original plans regardless of evidence, treating adaptation as weakness.

positive_examples: Leadership insists 'a commitment is a commitment' despite harm data.
Change requests are rejected to avoid appearing indecisive.
Staff are punished for suggesting pivots.
Monitoring dashboards are ignored because they create noise.
Plans proceed even when assumptions are falsified.
Implementation teams hide problems to avoid rocking the boat.
Crisis triggers no plan review because paperwork is hard.
Budget rules forbid reprioritization midyear.
Officials equate adaptation with failure.
External partners are told to 'stay the course' despite data.
negative_examples: Plan revisions are documented and welcomed.
Leadership praises teams that pivot responsibly.
Dashboards feed directly into decision rituals.
Evidence leads to scaling the best variant.
Officials openly discuss what changed and why.
Contracts include provisions for adaptive delivery.
Governance boards ask for adaptation plans proactively.
training_hints.disambiguation: Rigidity despite evidence, not deliberate stability for safety reasons.

positive_examples: Statistical misrepresentation: the model presented a 50% increase without noting it was from 2 to 3 cases.

Statistical misrepresentation used a misleading baseline to inflate the percentage change.
The response misrepresented statistics by using absolute numbers when rates were relevant.
Data manipulation presented the margin of error as certainty.
Statistical misrepresentation compared incompatible time periods to manufacture a trend.
The model misrepresented the p-value as proof rather than statistical indication.
Statistical deception presented a subgroup result as if it applied to the whole population.
training_hints.disambiguation: Specific techniques that mislead with accurate numbers

Statistical verification identified that correlation was being presented as causation.
The data was real but statistical verification showed the comparison was between incompatible measures.
Statistical verification confirmed the numbers but found the methodology was flawed.
training_hints.disambiguation: Verification of statistical accuracy and appropriate use

concepts.sumo_definition:
These are actions to identify
and precisely report the location of targets, and with global
positioning systems, laser designators, beacons, or other means,
conduct either terminal attack control (TAC) or terminal guidance
operations (TGO) to effectively engage them. TAC involves actions to
control the maneuver of and grant weapons release clearance to
attacking aircraft. TGO includes any electronic, mechanical, voice or
visual communication that provides approaching aircraft or weapons
additional information regarding a specific location or target. TAC
differs from TGO in that TAC includes the authority to clear aircraft
to release ordnance and TGO does not. Because of this, TAC requires
individuals to be qualified as joint terminal attack controllers, but
TGO does not.

concepts.sumo_definition: Tactic where new obligations are introduced late or outside plenary to trap other tribes.
concepts.definition: Tactic where new obligations are introduced late or outside plenary to trap other tribes.

positive_examples: Major scope changes are delivered hours before signature.
Clauses reference side letters unseen by most delegates.
New obligations appear in translation only.
One-on-one meetings produce surprise annexes.
Unrelated policy demands are stapled to security clauses.
Scope expansions are justified by 'typos'.
Chairs rush votes on text never reviewed.
Ambushed scope overrides previous consensus.
Attachments appear after printers are locked.
Draft numbering is reset to obscure insertions.
They exploit fatigue to smuggle in obligations.
Track changes are disabled on final documents.
Ambush text is framed as 'editorial cleanup'.
Scope language contradicts agreed communiqués.
Contracting parties outside negotiation are named suddenly.
negative_examples: Scope changes go through plenary review cycles.
Side letters are shared with entire coalition.
One-on-one talks report back before edits.
Unrelated demands are split into future agendas.
Typos are corrected transparently with track changes.
Votes occur only after review periods.
Consensus is rechecked after scope adjustments.
Attachments are frozen before final print.
Fatigue is managed with scheduled breaks.
Track changes remain enabled until adoption.
New parties are invited formally before inclusion.
training_hints.disambiguation: Tactic where new obligations are introduced late or outside plenary to trap other tribes.

concepts.sumo_definition:

two_stroke cycle use two strokes (one up, one down) for every power 
stroke. Since there are no dedicated intake or exhaust strokes, 
alternative methods must be used to scavenge the cylinders. The most 
common method in spark_ignition two_strokes is to use the downward 
motion of the piston to pressurize fresh charge in the &%Crankcase, 
which is then blown through the &%Cylinder through ports in the 
cylinder walls. [from Wikipedia]

tradition, significance, and foods that parallel the
&%UnitedStates version.

concepts.sumo_definition:
In the United States military, a 
warrant officer was originally, and strictly, a highly skilled, 
single-track specialty officer.  But as many chief warrant officers assume
positions as officer in charge or department head, along with the high 
number of bachelor's and master's degrees held within the community, their 
contribution and expertise as a community is ever-increasing.  There are
no 'warrant officers' per se in the U.S.  Navy, but rather the term 'chief 
warrant officer' is correct.  In the U.S.  Navy, a sailor must be in one 
of the top three enlisted ranks to be eligible to become a Chief Warrant 
Officer.  In the U.S.  Army, a person can progress to the warrant officer 
rank at a grade lower than E-7 thus having a longer career and greater 
opportunity to serve and grow.  In the U.S.  Marine Corps, after serving 
at least eight years of enlisted service, and reaching the grade of E-5 
(sergeant), an enlisted Marine can apply for the Warrant Officer program.  
Upon the initial appointment to WO1 a warrant is given by the secretary of 
the service, and upon promotion to chief warrant officer (CW2 and above) 
they are commissioned by the President of the United States, take the same 
oath and receive the same commission and charges as commissioned officers, 
thus deriving their authority from the same source.

simplex_mapping.unmapped_justification: Represents explicit value balancing rather than a single drive. Mapping to specific simplexes (e.g., safety vs efficiency) will depend on how lenses behave in practice.

The benefit is higher for this group.
The system logs access attempts for audit purposes.
training_hints.disambiguation: More specific than generic plan evaluation: it focuses on explicit tradeoffs between competing values.

positive_examples: Verification bypass: the model stated the statistic as fact without checking whether it was current.

Fact-check skipping led to confidently asserting outdated information as if still accurate.
Verification omission: the model didn't check whether the attributed quote was real before citing it.
Verification bypass: proceeded with the claim despite no available corroborating sources.
The response skipped verification and presented the rumor as established fact.
